MINISTRY OF EDUCATION AND TRAINING NATIONAL ECONOMICS UNIVERSITY | SOCIALIST REPUBLIC OF VIETNAM Independence – Freedom – Happiness
COURSE SYLLABUS (Issued attached Decision of NEU’s President,       ,            , 2023) | COURSE SYLLABUS (Issued attached Decision of NEU’s President,       ,            , 2023)
Bachelor of Software Engineering (SE) | Bachelor of Software Engineering (SE)

* Title: Integration and Deployment Management Code: CNTT11112
* Credits: 3 (45)
* Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
+ Lecture: 25 hrs.
+ Exercises in class: 10 hrs.
+ Presentation and Discussion: 10 hrs.
+ Self-study: 60 hrs.
* Parallel course(s):
* Prerequisite course(s): CNTT1128
* Department conducting the course:
+ Faculty: Information Technology; Room 1310, Building A1, National Economics University; Phone number: 024.36280.280 (6334)
+ Lecturers:
1. MSc. Phạm Thảo	Tel: 0966986689	Email: thaop@neu.edu.vn
2. PhD Lê Thị Hoài Thu 	Tel: 0912727529	Email: thulth@neu.edu.vn
* The course:

Foundation □ | Foundation □ | Fundamental (x) | Fundamental (x)
Compulsory □ | Elective □ | Compulsory □ | Elective (x)
* Course language: 	In English
* Meeting hour: 8AM – 11AM on Wednesdays, Room 13.10, Building A1, National Economics University

This course provides foundational knowledge in the ongoing process of software development and deployment, encompassing Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Delivery (CD). The primary goal of CI is to enable software developers to implement incremental changes to a codebase without compromising its quality. Throughout this course, students gain insight into various activities, tools, and deployment processes associated with CI/CD. Additionally, the course aims to cultivate skills in software development management, focusing on the integration and deployment of software. It also guides students in change management methodologies to enhance the efficiency of source code and mitigate associated risks. Practical exercises involve utilizing integrated development tools such as Git, conducting unit testing with Jasmine or Karma, and automation with Gulp and Jenkins. Furthermore, students will be organized into groups to explore various technologies more comprehensively, enabling them to present and discuss individual or group solutions to relevant issues.
The focus of the lessons is to provide:

- Understanding the core principles of DevOps and their relationship to CI/CD
- In-depth and practical knowledge of Unit Testing
- Comprehensive coverage of Source Control
- Practical exercises on integration testing
- Practice with big bang and incremental testing approaches.
- Establishment of a successful CI environment and pipeline
- Application of DevOps in business scenarios
- Business drivers for adopting DevOps in big data contexts.
- Introduction to Cloud Computing

* Textbooks/Lecture Notes:
[1] Continuous Integration, Delivery, and Deployment (2017), by Sander Rossel, Packt
* Additional references:

Table 4. Course goals
Goals | Goals Description | PLOs | Proficiency scale
G1 | This course provides foundational knowledge in the ongoing process of software development and deployment, encompassing Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Delivery (CD). The primary goal of CI is to enable software developers to implement incremental changes to a codebase without compromising its quality. Throughout this course, students gain insight into various activities, tools, and deployment processes associated with CI/CD. | PLO1.3 PLO1.4 PLO1.5 | 4
G2 | The course aims to cultivate skills in software development management, focusing on the integration and deployment of software. It also guides students in change management methodologies to enhance the efficiency of source code and mitigate associated risks. Practical exercises involve utilizing integrated development tools such as Git, conducting unit testing with Jasmine or Karma, and automation with Gulp and Jenkins | PLO2.2 | 4
G3 | The course contributes to the development of the ability to work independently or in a team, to properly understand the responsibility of job performance and professional ethics. | PLO3.1 PLO3.4 | 4, 4, 4

Table 5. Course learning outcomes (CLOs)
Goals | CLOs | CLOs Description | Teaching level (I, T, U)
G1 | CLO1.1 | The course provides fundamental knowledge of Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Delivery (CD). | I3
G1 | CLO1.2 | Develop skills in software development management, focusing on the integration and deployment of software. It also guides students in change management methodologies to enhance the efficiency of source code and mitigate associated risks | ITU4
- | CLO1.3 | Practical exercises involve utilizing integrated development tools such as Git, conducting unit testing with Jasmine or Karma, and automation with Gulp and Jenkins. | ITU4
G2 | CLO2.1 | The students have skilled in searching, synthesizing, analyzing, and using CI, CD, and testing tool | TU4
G3 | CLO3.1 | Ability to self-study CI, CD, and testing tool related materials to complete assigned assignments. | U4
G3 | CLO3.2 | Consciously organize class discipline, comply with classroom rules, have a spirit of cooperation and personal responsibility for the exercises assigned by the lecturer. | U4
G3 | CLO3.3 | Proper understanding of responsibility in job performance, professional ethics in work related to integration and deployment of software. | U4

Table 6. Assessment summary
Assessments | CLOs | Weighting (%) | Week
Formative assessment | Formative assessment | Formative assessment | Formative assessment
Participant: Learning attitude Answers questions Discussions | CLO1.x CLO2.x CLO3.x | 10% | 1,2,3,4,5 ,7,8,9,10,11
Midterm assessment | Midterm assessment | Midterm assessment | Midterm assessment
Group Project Presentation | CLO 3.1, 3.2, 4.1, 4.2 CLO 3.1, 3.2, 4.1, 4.2 | 20% | 12
Group Project Report | CLO 3.1, 3.2, 4.1, 4.2 CLO 3.1, 3.2, 4.1, 4.2 | 20% | 13
Summative assessment | Summative assessment | Summative assessment | Summative assessment
Final exam | All CLOs | 50% | As scheduled

Table 7.1. Lesson plan for the course
Week | Content | Readings requirement | CLO | Teaching and Learning Activities | Assessment tools and criteria
[1] | [2] | [3] | [4] | [5] | [6]
1 | Introduce • Course outlines • Development environment and support tools | Course outline | CLO1.1 CLO3.1 | Introduction to course Announce classroom rules. Instructions for installing the IDE | Level of participation Level of interaction Quality of answers
2-3 | Chapter 1: Introduction, basic concept, and definitions Introduction to Software Development Overview of Continuous Integration (CI) Overview of Continuous Delivery (CD) Principles of DevOps Software Integration Software Testing | [1] Chapter 1, 2, 3 | CLO1.1 CLO2.1 CLO3.x | Reading at home Lecturing Group discussion in class | Participation Interaction Answer Quality
4-5 | Chapter 2: Working with the CI Environment and Source Control 2.1. Setting up a CI Environment (Such as Jenkins) 2.2. Version Control with Git 2.3. Automation with Gulp 2.4. Automation with Jenkins 2.5. Other tools | [1] Chapter 2, 3 | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO2.1 CLO3.x | Reading at home Lecturing Group discussion in class | Participation Interaction Answer Quality
6-7 | Chapter 3: Testing 3.1. A Node JS and MongoDB Web Application | [1] Chapter 3 | CLO1.2 CLO3.x | Reading at home Lecturing Group discussion in class | Participation Interaction Answer Quality
8-9 | Chapter 3: Testing 3.2 A C# .NET Core and Postgres SQL Web App | [1] Chapter 3 | CLO1.2 CLO3.x | Reading at home Lecturing Group discussion in class | Participation Interaction Answer Quality
10 | Chapter 3: Testing 3.3 Jenkins Plugins 3.4 Jenkins Pipelines 3.5 JUnit 3.6 Selenium | [1] Chapter 3 | CLO1.2 CLO3.x | Reading at home Lecturing Group discussion in class | Participation Interaction Answer Quality
11-12 | Chapter 3: Testing 3.5 Testing a Web API | [1] Chapter 3 | CLO1.2 CLO1.3 CLO2.1 CLO3.x | Reading at home Lecturing Group discussion in class | Participation Interaction Answer Quality
13-14 | Group project presentation | - | CLO1.1 CLO1.2 CLO3.x | Group presentation. | Participation Group presentation
- Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches five points or more (on the scale of 10).

chunks.text:
- Students are responsible for attending all classes. In the case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, one point will be deducted one point. Students who miss classes more than three times, with or without reason, will be considered failing to complete the course and must re-register.
- Students will be awarded points for constructive comments. These points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
chunks.breadcrumbs: 8. COURSE REQUIREMENT & EXPECTATION > 8.2. Requirements for attending classes.

chunks.text:
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behavior that affects the teaching and learning process is prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students over 10 minutes late after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
- Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

PhD Pham Xuan Lam | Prof. PhD Pham Hong Chuong

2. COURSE DESCRIPTIONS
This course provides foundational knowledge in the ongoing process of software development and deployment, encompassing Continuous Integration (CI) and Continuous Delivery (CD). 2-3 | Chapter 1: Introduction, basic concept, and definitions Introduction to Software Development Overview of Continuous Integration (CI) Overview of Continuous Delivery (CD) Principles of DevOps Software Integration Software Testing | [1] Chapter 1, 2, 3 | CLO1.1 CLO2.1 CLO3.x | Reading at home Lecturing Group discussion in class | Participation Interaction Answer Quality

8. COURSE REQUIREMENT & EXPECTATION
8.1. Requirements for taking final /terminal exams.
- Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches five points or more (on the scale of 10).
8.2. Requirements for attending classes.
- Students are responsible for attending all classes. In the case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, one point will be deducted one point. Students who miss classes more than three times, with or without reason, will be considered failing to complete the course and must re-register.
- Students will be awarded points for constructive comments. These points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
- Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
8.3. Requirements for in-class behavior
- The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behavior that affects the teaching and learning process is prohibited.
- Students must come to class on time. Students over 10 minutes late after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
- Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
Faculty Dean | NEU’s President
PhD Pham Xuan Lam | Prof. PhD Pham Hong Chuong
